I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Indonesia has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance 
for  the  implementation  of  an  anti-money  laundering  law,  to  be  enacted  shortly,  and  the 
development  of  an  anti-money  laundering  regime.  At  the  Consultative  Group  on  Indonesia1 
quarterly  meeting  held  on  20  February  2002,  the  Government  stated  its  commitment  to 
macrostability and advancing needed reforms including structures inhibiting money laundering. 
Strengthening existing institutions’ capabilities, the development of newly established institutions 
and systems for monitoring suspicious transactions, and training of officials will be key. This 
technical assistance (TA) will improve financial governance, promote the soundness and stability 
of Indonesia’s financial system, and help protect an integrated global financial system that could 
be undermined through money laundering activities. Money laundering also makes countries 
vulnerable to other kinds of crimes such as drug trafficking, trafficking in people, fraud, and 
corruption. This vulnerability leads to poor governance and undermines state institutions and their 
legitimacy, thereby posing a serious threat to sound economic development.  
 
2.  ADB  is  an  Observer  International  Organization  of  the  Asia/Pacific  Group  on  Money 
Laundering  (APG),2  the  leading  forum  in  the  region,  and  has  supported  and  contributed  to 
regional efforts against money laundering. Anti-money laundering issues are strategic to ADB 
reform  measures  in  the  context  of  its  two  key  policies  on  governance  and  anti-corruption. 
Enactment of anti-money laundering legislation is also an outstanding condition for release of the 
third tranche and final tranche of $350 million under the Indonesia Financial Governance Reform 
Sector Development Program Loan.3 
 
3.  The development of a common regional approach for countries is important to promote 
standard  guidelines,  definitions,  practices,  and  systems  that  can  facilitate  and  enhance  the 
identification of cross-border money laundering transactions. ADB’s regional TA for Countering 
Money Laundering in the Asian and Pacific Region4 includes a survey to assess anti-money 
laundering  issues  to  support  development  of  a  regional  framework  to  counter  the  practice. 
Indonesia is one of nine countries examined under this regional TA. ADB has also been assisting 
the Government in adopting policies and procedures to mitigate the use of businesses as a 
vehicle  for  money  laundering.  The  focus  of  those  operations  has  been  to  strengthen  the 
regulators’ market vigilance; improve the quality and reporting of information; and develop proper 
rules on governance, disclosure, and transparency in relation to shareholdings and beneficial 
ownership. The proposed TA will link and build upon these efforts, provide immediate critical 
support for implementation of an anti-money laundering law, develop relevant institutions, and 
provide capacity building and training.5  The TA framework is given in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES OR PROBLEMS 
 
4.   The United Nations targeted 2003 for all countries to have enacted appropriate national 
legislation  to  end  money  laundering,  estimated  at  $200  billion  worldwide.  Action  at  the

2  
 
international level to combat the practice began in 1988 with two key initiatives: (i) the Basel 
Committee on Banking Regulations and Supervisory Practices, which issued a Statement of 
Principles on money laundering controls based on (a) avoidance of suspicious transactions, 
(b) cooperation with law enforcement authorities, and (c) “know your customer” rules; and (ii) the 
United Nations Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, 
which has now been ratified by over 140 countries. The latter is the first multilateral, legally 
binding  instrument  to  address  the  issue  of  money  laundering.  Its  provisions  encourage 
international cooperation to identify, trace, seize, and confiscate the proceeds of drug trafficking 
and  to  prosecute  those  responsible  for  laundering  illicit  profits.  Similarly,  the  International 
Organization  of  Securities  Commissions  has  issued  guidance;  and  in  January  2002,  the 
International  Association  of  Insurance  Supervisors  issued  Anti-Money  Laundering  Guidance 
Notes for Insurance Supervisors and Insurance Entities.    
 
5.  Indonesia’s lack of anti-money laundering measures resulted in June 2001 in the Financial 
Action Task Force on Money Laundering (FATF) adding the country to its list of Non-Cooperative 
Countries and Territories following the FATF assessment of its anti-money laundering regime.  
FATF is an independent international body established by the Group of Seven Summit in 1989 
whose membership consists of 29 governments and 2 international organizations (the European 
Commission and the Gulf Co-operation Council). FATF also collaborates closely with APG and 
others to extend its fight against financial crimes. FATF develops and promotes policies, both 
nationally and internationally, to combat money laundering. It has issued 40 recommendations to 
fight money laundering, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank have 
recognized the “FATF 40” as one of the 12 core standards for sound financial systems. FATF 
encourages self-assessment and mutual evaluation exercises to determine the compliance of 
countries with its recommendations. At this time, Indonesia meets only nine criteria and partially 
meets four others. Overall, Indonesia lacks a basic set of anti-money laundering provisions; core 
areas of weakness include 
 
(i)  no law recognizing money laundering as a criminal offense, 
(ii)  no  mandatory  system  of  reporting  suspicious  transactions  to  a  financial 
intelligence unit, and  
(iii)  no customer identification regulations for nonbank financial institutions. 
 
6.  Failure to take necessary steps to remedy these identified deficiencies will result in the 
imposition of countermeasures by FATF members, which could severely impact correspondent 
banking and other areas. To rectify the deficiencies, the Government drafted the anti-money 
laundering law, Law Concerning Eradication of Money Laundering Criminal Acts, which was 
submitted to Parliament in January 2001. ADB provided detailed comments on the draft law under 
TA 5967-REG (footnote 4).  It is presently under consideration and is hoped to be approved by 
June 2002 to avoid the imposition of countermeasures. The Ministry of Justice and Human Rights 
(MJHR) coordinated the preparation of the law and its submission to Parliament, and will prepare 
enabling regulations and coordinate the establishment of the Commission to Combat Money 
Laundering (KPTPPU) and the Center for Financial Transaction and Reporting Analysis (PPATK), 
new institutions to be established under the new law. The Working Group on Money Laundering 
assists MJHR and includes representatives from (i) the Ministry of Finance (MOF)  Directorate 
General of Financial Institutions (DGFI) and Badan Pengawas Pasar Modal (BAPEPAM), (ii) 
Bank Indonesia (BI), (iii) the Attorney General’s Office, (iv) the police, (v) Badan Pengawas 
Keuangan dan Pembangunan (BPKP), and (vi) the Ministry of Home Affairs. 
 
7.  Enactment of appropriate legislation is only the first step in establishing a foundation for 
an effective anti-money laundering regime. Critical issues and challenges remain to be addressed

3  
 
in  order  to  achieve  a  working  system  to  combat  the  practice.  The  new  law  requires  the 
establishment of a commission (KPTPPU) and a center for financial transaction and reporting 
analysis (PPATK). However, those bodies’ roles and functions must be elaborated to ensure 
effective operations; appropriate staff must be selected; significant capacity building and training 
must be undertaken; and sufficient budget needs to be allocated to support initial operations. 
 
8.  A fundamental lack of infrastructure and systems to support the monitoring, analysis and 
investigation of suspicious transactions is also a critical issue. Some information technology (IT) 
requirements for PPATK for FATF reporting have been assessed;6 however the broader IT 
requirements for PPATK and KPTPPU have not. The current IT assessment addresses only a 
basic core system, but does not cover IT requirements for the general administration, accounting 
and day-to-day operations of PPATK and KPTPPU; nor does it provide additional capacity for 
sophisticated  analyses  of  suspicious  transactions  submitted  to  PPATK  to  determine  those 
transactions that should be investigated. Management information system assistance should also 
be provided to support the system’s development and implementation in relevant institutions to 
ensure an effective monitoring and reporting of suspicious transactions to PPATK.  In general, the 
large banks are expected to have this capacity; however, in the nonbank sector and for some of 
the  smaller  banks,  insufficient  capacity  and  systems  may  be  an  issue.  Although  reporting 
transactions  of  Rp100,000,0007  or  more  may  be  straightforward,  detecting  patterns  of 
transactions falling below the threshold may require sophisticated software, analyses, and skills. 
PPATK could develop basic monitoring software for distribution to covered institutions at nominal 
cost,  thus  ensuring  sufficient  standardization  across  covered  institutions.  However,  an 
assessment should be conducted to determine costs and benefits for small and medium-sized 
banks and nonbank financial institutions to effectively implement such systems. Another core 
issue is the lack of skills base, knowledge, and institutional capacity for anti-money laundering 
activities. Basic training on money laundering principles, trends and patterns, possible deterrent 
actions,  forensic  accounting,  auditing,  and  investigative  techniques  is  essential  for  existing 
institutions and for the planned PPATK and KPTPPU. The fact that there is little understanding or 
even awareness among the public and regulated entities of money laundering as a crime and its 
impact is also an issue to be addressed. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
9.  The purpose of the proposed TA is to develop an effective anti-money laundering regime 
to increase the soundness of Indonesia’s financial system, economic development, and good 
governance. Better controls for money laundering will add to the stability of Indonesia’s financial 
system;  support  a  sound,  integrated  financial  system  in  a  global  economy;  and  reduce 
vulnerabilities  to  other  types  of  crimes  such  as  drug  trafficking,  trafficking  in  people,  and 
corruption. The TA will build upon the country-specific legal analysis provided by TA 5967-REG 
and support Indonesia’s integration in a regional plan for countering money laundering. This TA 
will support the implementation of anti-money laundering law and regulations, the establishment 
of new institutions mandated by the law, and the development of monitoring and database 
systems; increase the skills base and institutional capacity necessary for an effective anti-money 
laundering regime; and promote public awareness and understanding of money laundering and of 
the impact of the new law.  
 
                                                           
6   AusAID has prepared an assessment and budget for basic information technology requirements of PPATK. 
7   Equivalent to $9,759 based on exchange rate of $1=Rp10,247 as of 15 February 2002.

4  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The  proposed  TA  will  be  conducted  in  consultation  and  coordination  with  the 
Government’s Working Group on Money Laundering. As the KPTPPU becomes operational, 
consultation and coordination of the TA will shift to KPTPPU if the Working Group is dissolved, or 
lie with both bodies if a continuing role for the Working Group is maintained. Assistance provided 
under this TA will also be undertaken in collaboration and consultation with APG.8  APG facilitates 
the adoption, implementation, and enforcement of internationally accepted anti-money laundering 
standards throughout the Asia and Pacific Region. Substantial progress has been made including 
enactment of legislation in many countries, agreement by APG members to participate in mutual 
evaluations,  better  understanding  of  and  action  against  money  laundering  methods,  and 
increased information exchange. 
 
11.  ADB has been coordinating closely on the subject of anti-money laundering, with other 
agencies including the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), United States 
Agency for International Development (USAID), Department for International Development of the 
United  Kingdom,  IMF,  World  Bank,  United  Nations,  and  Asia-Europe  Meeting  Anti-Money 
Laundering Initiative (ASEM).9 Aid coordination meetings were held in Jakarta in December 2001 
and January-February 2002. The World Bank is addressing money laundering issues through the 
introduction of a new module in its Financial Sector Assessment Program (FSAP). This module is 
being piloted in the current FSAP for Switzerland, which is underway, and Indonesia is not 
scheduled for an FSAP before 2003. IMF, in cooperation with the United Nations, Office for Drug 
Control  and  Crime  Prevention  in  Vienna,  conducted  an  assessment  in  February  2002  of 
Indonesian Government and aid agency activities to address money laundering and the potential 
role for IMF. Although no action plan has yet been presented by IMF, the possibility of some 
short-term TA was discussed. AusAID has been providing core short-term assistance and will 
support  the  Government  in  preparing  amendments  to  the  draft  law  based  on  consolidated 
comments from funding agencies and other parties to be considered in Parliament for decision in 
March  2002.  USAID  indicated  that  a  small  amount  of  funds  could  be  made  available  for 
immediate assistance to supplement AusAID’s efforts. This proposed TA is presently the only 
significant medium-term assistance being discussed among aid agencies, and will play a critical 
role in supporting the implementation, development, and capacity building necessary for an 
effective  anti-money  laundering  regime.  Longer-term  support  is  also  planned  under  ADB’s 
proposed  Financial  Governance  and  Social  Security  Reform  Program  Loan,  for  which  a 
memorandum of understanding was signed with the Government in February 2002. ADB will 
continue to coordinate closely with other donors during TA implementation. 
 
12.  This TA will (i) support implementation of the new anti-money laundering law; (ii) provide 
assistance in the establishment and development of KPTPPU and PPATK; (iii) provide a training 
needs assessment and program for capacity building and training for key existing institutions and 
for  KPTPPU  and  PPATK;  (iv)  assess  options  and  alternatives  for  suspicious  transactions 
monitoring systems and a database for PPATK and systems of covered institutions, and provide 
a recommended action plan with estimated budget for systems implementation; (v) develop 
guidance notes for financial institutions in the reporting of suspicious transactions; (vi) conduct 
training for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and the judiciary in the enforcement of the anti-

5  
 
money laundering law; and (vii) hold public workshops to include the private sector in Jakarta and 
the major provinces to increase awareness of money laundering as a crime and related issues 
(“socialization” of the law). Attempts to strengthen the implementation of customer identification 
regulations10  in  an  environment,  such  as  Indonesia,  where  unique  identity  documents  (e.g., 
passports) are not widespread could create potential barriers to access to the formal financial 
system that would disproportionately affect poorer segments of the population. Costs of the 
systems  needed  for  financial  institutions  to  comply  with  regulations  could  also  have  anti-
competitive effects by favoring a small number of larger institutions better able to absorb them. 
This TA will address these potential risks, and support the development of measures that balance 
the  need  for  an  effective  anti-money  laundering  regime  with  the  need  to  maintain  market 
competition and adequate access to services provided by the formal financial sector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.875 million equivalent comprising a foreign exchange cost 
of $1.165 million and a local currency cost of $0.71 million equivalent.  The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $1.5 million equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$0.335 million equivalent of the local currency cost, on a grant basis from the Asian Currency 
Crisis Support Facility funded by the Government of Japan, or from other TA resources available 
to ADB.  The Government will provide the remaining $0.375 million equivalent through the 
provision of counterpart staff, office space, and contingencies. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The executing agency for the TA will be the MJHR, and the implementing agencies will be 
(i) BI, (ii) the Directorate General of Financial Institutions in MOF, (iii) BAPEPAM in MOF, (iv) the 
Ministry of Home Affairs, (v) BPKP (Financial and Development Supervisory Board), (vi) the 
Attorney General’s Office, and (vii) the police. All the implementing agencies are members of the 
Government’s Working Group on Money Laundering. It is estimated that 47 person-months of 
consulting services will be required, comprising 22 person-months of international and 25 person-
months of domestic services. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are provided in 
Appendix  3.  A  firm  will  be  selected  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. The consultants will provide inception, quarterly, and final reports. The consultants 
will submit the inception report within one month of TA commencement, which will be discussed 
and agreed upon at a tripartite meeting of the consultants, the Government, and ADB. A midterm 
review will be conducted to discuss the findings and progress of the TA. The consultants will 
submit a draft final report for review at a tripartite meeting and will incorporate comments in the 
final TA report. The TA implementation period will be 18 months and is planned to commence by 
July 2002 and to be completed by December 2003. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S RECOMMENDATION 
 
15.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance, 
on a grant basis, to the Government of Indonesia in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of 
$1,500,000 for the purpose of the Development of an Anti-Money Laundering Regime.

Appendix 3, page 1 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants1 
 
1.   A total of 22 person-months of international consulting services will be required, comprised 
as follows: 
 
1.  Anti-Money Laundering Expert(s)/ Team Leader(s) (10 person-months) 
 
2.  The team leader will be responsible for the overall management of the technical assistance 
(TA), report on team work and issues; and ensure timely delivery of the inception, interim, and final 
reports. The consultant must have expertise in the financial and legal aspects of money laundering; 
and extensive experience in the implementation of anti-money laundering legislation, investigation, 
and/or prosecution of money laundering cases in developed countries with an effective anti-money 
laundering regime. Given the number of person-months and the range of skills, it is considered that 
more than one person may assume the team leader position. The consultant will, in cooperation 
and  consultation  with  Asia/Pacific  Group  on  Money  Laundering,  and  in  coordination  with 
consultants working under ADB TA 5967-REG for Countering Money Laundering in the Asian and 
Pacific Region, do the following: 
  
(i)  Assist in the establishment of supporting institutions Commission to Combat Money 
Laundering [KPTPPU] and Center for Financial Transaction and Reporting Analysis 
[PPATK] to be mandated under the new anti-money laundering legislation. Assist in

2.  Forensic Accounting Expert (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The  consultant  must  have  significant  expertise  in  the  forensic  accounting  of  money 
laundering cases involving, but not limited to, the securities and insurance industries. The expert 
will do the following: 
 
(i)  Review and comment on proposed rules and regulations on reporting requirements 
for suspicious transactions; 
 
(ii)  Assist other team members in the design of a due diligence program for concerned 
regulators, especially in the securities and insurance industries. This will include 
recommendations and basic training on developing an investigative database and 
asset tracing guidelines; 
 
(iii)  Undertake basic training for and impart awareness to officials and staff concerning 
forensic accounting principles and detecting money-laundering activities,

(iv)  Assist the team leader in the preparation of guidance notes for financial institutions 
in the reporting of suspicious transactions. 
 
3.  Database/Financial Intelligence Unit Expert (3 person-months) 
 
4.  The  consultant  must  have  significant  expertise  and  experience  in  the  design  and 
implementation of anti-money laundering systems, monitoring procedures, and processes. The 
expert will perform the following: 
 
(i)  Review the monitoring and surveillance systems of concerned agencies with a view 
to incorporating reporting requirements for suspicious transactions in the covered 
institutions under the anti-money laundering legislation and in compliance with FATF 
recommendations. 
 
(ii)  Assess the options and alternatives for an FIU monitoring system, analytical tools, 
and database to enable analysts to effectively identify trends and patterns in money 
laundering. 
 
(iii)  Provide  recommendations  and  an  action  plan  with  an  estimated  budget  for 
comprehensive systems design, development, and training.  
 
(iv)  Identify  cost-effective  compliance  systems  and  industry-wide  cost-sharing 
mechanisms for systems development, and provide recommendations for FIU. In 
consultation with the team leader, assess the costs of compliance for small and 
medium-sized banks and nonbank financial institutions and compare to expected 
benefits. 
 
4.  Law Enforcement Expert (3 person-months) 
 
5.  The  consultant  must  have  significant  expertise  in  law  enforcement,  criminal  and  civil 
enforcement proceedings, and investigation of money laundering cases involving, but not limited 
to, the securities and insurance industries. The expert will do the following: 
 
(i)  Develop a plan for the training of law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and the 
judiciary in the enforcement of anti-money laundering law. 
 
(ii)  Identify appropriate participants for training and institutional needs. 
 
(iii)  Prepare  training  materials  for  law  enforcement  officers,  prosecutors,  and  the 
judiciary. 
 
(iv)  Conduct initial training for government officials and trainers to enable continuing in-
house training for junior and middle level staff. 
 
5.  Securities and Banking Expert (3 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant must have significant expertise in the financial and legal aspects of money 
laundering, compliance, and institutional training. The expert will perform the following:

(i)  Review compliance requirements for banks, insurance companies, securities market

B.  Domestic Consultants  
 
7.  A  total  of  25  person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services  will  be  required.  The 
consultants must have knowledge of the financial and legal aspects of money laundering; strong 
research capabilities; and extensive experience in one or more areas including, but not limited to, 
law enforcement and investigation, financial markets regulation and supervision, management 
information system development and design, and institutional training. 
 
8.  The responsibilities of the domestic consultants will include, but not be limited to, the 
following: 
 
(i)  Assist the international consultants to identify institutional reforms needed to comply 
with FATF requirements and other international initiatives including those of the 
Basel Committee on Banking Regulations and Supervisory Practices, the United 
Nations  Convention  against  Illicit  Traffic  in  Narcotic  Drugs  and  Psychotropic 
Substances, IOSCO, and the International Association of Insurance Supervisors. 
 
(i)  Help  the  international  consultants  prepare  internal  procedures  and  controls  for 
PPATK, KPTPPU, and other agencies concerned. 
 
(ii)  Assist  in  the  preparation  of  training  materials  and  participate  in  the  training  of 
officials and staff on money laundering principles and possible deterrent actions. 
 
(iii)  Help the international consultants develop and deliver public workshops to promote 
public and institutional awareness of money laundering, its importance, and the 
impact of the new anti-money laundering legislation. 
 
(iv)  Obtain assistance, data, and information from officials required to accomplish the 
objectives of the TA.  
 
(v)  Submit  written  reports  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  Asia/Pacific  Group  on 
Money Laundering, and the international consultants, as required.
